volsense_inference packageïƒ

Submodulesïƒ

volsense_inference.analytics moduleïƒ

VolSense Analytics â€” Trader Snapshot Moduleïƒ

Lightweight analytical layer for daily volatility forecasts. Generates actionable metrics, relative signals, and visualizations for multi-ticker forecasts without requiring historical data.

This module is intended for use within volsense_inference.

class Analytics(preds: DataFrame, vol_regime_quantiles: List[float] = [0.2, 0.8])[source]ïƒ

Bases: object

Trader-facing analytics for VolSense forecasts.

Parameters:

  • preds (pandas.DataFrame) â€“ DataFrame with columns like [â€˜tickerâ€™,â€™realized_volâ€™,â€™pred_vol_1â€™, â€¦].

  • vol_regime_quantiles (list[float], optional) â€“ Quantile thresholds (low, high) for regime classification.

Raises:

ValueError â€“ If an empty or None forecast DataFrame is provided.

compute() → DataFrame[source]ïƒ

Compute cross-sectional volatility analytics for a single snapshot.

Derives per-horizon metrics:

  • f/r ratio: forecast_vol / realized_vol

  • z-score: cross-sectional z-score vs realized_vol mean/std

  • signal_strength: clipped z-score in [-3, 3]

  • vol_regime: â€˜Low Volâ€™ | â€˜Normalâ€™ | â€˜High Volâ€™ via quantiles

Returns:

Processed DataFrame with added per-horizon columns and â€˜vol_regimeâ€™.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

describe(ticker: str, horizon: str = 'pred_vol_5') → str[source]ïƒ

Produce a human-readable interpretation for a single ticker.

The message encodes direction via f/r ratio (>1 rising, <1 easing), the cross-sectional z-score, and the volatility regime.

Parameters:

  • ticker (str) â€“ Ticker to describe.

  • horizon (str) â€“ Horizon column to reference (e.g., â€˜pred_vol_5â€™).

Returns:

Short interpretation string for trader consumption.

Return type:

str

plot(horizon: str = 'pred_vol_5', show: bool = False)[source]ïƒ

Scatter plot of forecast vs realized volatility at a selected horizon.

Each ticker is plotted as a labeled point; includes a 45-degree reference line.

Parameters:

  • horizon (str) â€“ Horizon column to plot (e.g., â€˜pred_vol_5â€™).

  • show (bool) â€“ If True, render and close the figure; if False, return the Figure.

Returns:

Matplotlib Figure when show=False; otherwise None.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure or None

summary(horizon: str = 'pred_vol_5') → DataFrame[source]ïƒ

Summarize realized vs forecast metrics for each ticker.

Returns a compact table with:

[â€˜tickerâ€™,â€™realized_volâ€™,â€™forecast_volâ€™,â€™f/r_ratioâ€™,â€™zscoreâ€™,â€™vol_regimeâ€™].

If the requested horizon is absent, falls back to the first available â€˜pred_vol_*â€™ column.

Parameters:

horizon (str) â€“ Horizon column to summarize (e.g., â€˜pred_vol_5â€™).

Returns:

Ticker-level summary sorted by descending z-score.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

volsense_inference.dashboard moduleïƒ

Streamlit dashboard for VolSense.

Provides a small interactive UI to run forecasts, inspect per-ticker plots, sector heatmaps and cross-sectional signals. â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

This module exposes the Streamlit application and several helper functions:

  • _parse_tickers() - parse user comma-separated tickers

  • _safe_style_format() - style numeric columns for display

  • _detect_horizons() - detect forecast horizons from dataframe columns

  • _load_forecast_model() - cached model loader

  • run_volsense() - run forecasts + signals (cached)

  • export_csv_button() - download button for DataFrame CSV export

Typical usageïƒ

Run the Streamlit app:

streamlit run volsense_inference/dashboard.py
export_csv_button(df: DataFrame, filename: str, label: str = 'ğŸ“¥ Export CSV')[source]ïƒ

Create a Streamlit download button that exports a DataFrame as CSV.

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) â€“ DataFrame to export.

  • filename (str) â€“ Suggested filename for the downloaded CSV.

  • label (str) â€“ Button label text.

Returns:

None

run_volsense(model_version: str, checkpoints_dir: str, start: str, tickers: List[str])[source]ïƒ

Run VolSense forecasts and compute analytics and signals.

This function is cached for 30 minutes to avoid repeated expensive runs.

Parameters:

  • model_version (str) â€“ Model version to use for forecasting.

  • checkpoints_dir (str) â€“ Directory with model artifacts.

  • start (str) â€“ Start date string for feature fetch.

  • tickers (List[str]) â€“ List of tickers to forecast.

Returns:

Tuple (Forecast instance, predictions DataFrame, analytics object, analytics summary DataFrame, SignalEngine instance, signals DataFrame)

Return type:

tuple

volsense_inference.forecast_engine moduleïƒ

volsense_inference.forecast_engineïƒ

High-level forecasting runtime for VolSense.

This module exposes the Forecast runtime class which orchestrates data fetching, feature engineering, batch inference against a pretrained VolSense model, and lightweight analytics and visualization helpers.

Primary classïƒ

Forecast

  • Loads a pretrained model and its artifacts (scalers, metadata, feature list) via volsense_inference.model_loader.load_model.

  • Prepares recent market data using volsense_core.data.fetch.build_dataset and volsense_core.data.feature_engineering.build_features to ensure the inference inputs match the training-time schema.

  • Runs batched inference using volsense_inference.predictor.predict_batch, attaches realized volatility values, and exposes an Analytics helper for cross-sectional signal computations and simple plots.

Usage exampleïƒ

>>> from volsense_inference.forecast_engine import Forecast
>>> f = Forecast(model_version="v507", checkpoints_dir="../models", start="2020-01-01")
>>> preds = f.run(["SPY", "QQQ"])
>>> f.plot("SPY")

Notes

  • The Forecast class expects model artifacts to be available in the checkpoints directory (meta + state or supported bundle format). See volsense_inference.model_loader for loading behavior and supported formats.

  • Forecast.plot produces a matplotlib Figure when show=False, otherwise it renders and closes the figure to avoid duplicate captures in notebook contexts.

class Forecast(model_version: str = 'v109', checkpoints_dir: str = 'models', start: str = '2005-01-01')[source]ïƒ

Bases: object

High-level runtime interface for volatility forecasting and visualization.

Orchestrates:

  • recent data fetch and feature engineering aligned to the trained model,

  • batched inference for one or more tickers,

  • attachment of realized volatility for the snapshot date,

  • light analytics and plotting helpers.

Version tag of the pretrained model assets to load.

Type:

str

Directory containing model checkpoints and metadata.

Type:

Earliest date used when fetching recent data to build features.

Type:

str

Loaded model ready for batch prediction.

Type:

object

Model metadata (e.g., horizons, window).

Type:

Per-ticker scalers used during training.

Type:

dict

Mapping of ticker symbols to integer IDs.

Type:

Input window length used by the model.

Lookback window for realized volatility computation in feature prep.

Forecast horizons supported by the model.

Plot realized volatility history and overlay constant forecast levels by horizon.

Draws:

  • Realized volatility time series for recent months.

  • Horizontal dashed lines for each available predicted horizon.

  • Optional VIX overlay if provided.

Parameters:

  • ticker (str) â€“ Ticker symbol to visualize.

  • show_vix (bool) â€“ Whether to overlay VIX time series (requires vix_df).

  • vix_df (pandas.DataFrame, optional) â€“ DataFrame with columns [â€˜dateâ€™,â€™closeâ€™] representing VIX levels.

  • show (bool) â€“ If True, render the plot and return None; if False, return the Figure.

Raises:

  • RuntimeError â€“ If .run() has not been called prior to plotting.

  • ValueError â€“ If no forecast results are available for the requested ticker.

Returns:

Matplotlib Figure when show=False; otherwise None.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure or None

Generate multi-horizon forecasts for one or more tickers.

Prepares recent data, runs batched predictions, attaches realized volatility, and computes cross-sectional analytics for convenience.

volsense_inference.model_loader moduleïƒ

Model loader utilities for VolSense inference.

This module provides a single entrypoint load_model() which locates and loads model artifacts saved in one of three supported formats:

  • legacy â€œ.full.pklâ€ (pickled model or bundle)

  • combined â€œ<stem>_bundle.pklâ€ (dict with state + meta)

  • portable â€œ<stem>.meta.jsonâ€ + â€œ<stem>.pthâ€ (state_dict + metadata)

All loaders return a tuple:

(model, meta, scalers, ticker_to_id, features)

The module focuses on safe CPU-device loading and conservative defaults so artifacts saved on different environments (Colab, local) can be loaded reliably.

Sphinx-style documentation is provided on public helpers.

load_model(model_version: str, checkpoints_dir: str = 'models', device: str = 'cpu')[source]ïƒ

Universal VolSense model loader.

This function attempts to locate and load artifacts for model_version from checkpoints_dir. Supported artifact layouts (priority order):

  1. <stem>.full.pkl

  2. <stem>_bundle.pkl

  3. <stem>.meta.json + <stem>.pth

The returned tuple contains:

(model, meta, scalers, ticker_to_id, features)

Parameters:

  • model_version (str) â€“ Version identifier matching checkpoint stems (e.g. â€œglobal_vol_forecaster_multi_v507â€).

  • checkpoints_dir (str) â€“ Relative directory name containing model artifacts.

  • device (str) â€“ Torch device to move the loaded model to (default â€œcpuâ€).

Returns:

Tuple with loaded model and auxiliary metadata/assets.

Return type:

tuple

Raises:

FileNotFoundError â€“ If no supported artifact layout is found for the version.

Example:
>>> model, meta, scalers, t2i, features = load_model("global_vol_forecaster_multi_v507", "models", device="cpu")

volsense_inference.predictor moduleïƒ

VolSense Inference â€” Predictorïƒ

Helper utilities to run single and batched predictions with pretrained VolSense models.

Responsibilities: - Resolve the expected feature list from model metadata or user override. - Apply per-ticker scaling using training-time scalers, with sensible fallbacks. - Execute model forward passes with optional ticker ID conditioning. - Produce per-ticker predictions and aggregate batch results. - Attach latest realized volatility for comparison and derive simple diffs.

Used by volsense_inference.forecast_engine.Forecast.

attach_realized(df_preds: DataFrame, df_recent: DataFrame) → DataFrame[source]ïƒ

Attach the latest realized volatility to each forecast row and compute diffs.

When df_recent contains â€˜realized_volâ€™, merges the most recent value per ticker into df_preds, then computes simple diagnostics:

  • vol_diff = pred_vol_1 - realized_vol

  • vol_direction = sign(vol_diff)

If â€˜realized_volâ€™ is not available in df_recent, the input df_preds is returned unchanged.

Parameters:

  • df_preds (pandas.DataFrame) â€“ DataFrame of predictions with one row per ticker.

  • df_recent (pandas.DataFrame) â€“ Recent feature DataFrame containing realized volatility history.

Returns:

DataFrame augmented with â€˜realized_volâ€™ and derived diagnostics when available.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

predict_batch(model: Any, meta: Dict[str, Any], df: DataFrame, tickers: List[str], scalers: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, ticker_to_id: Dict[str, int] | None = None, features: List[str] | None = None) → DataFrame[source]ïƒ

Run predictions for a list of tickers and return a tidy DataFrame.

Exceptions for individual tickers are caught and printed; failed tickers are skipped.

Parameters:

  • model (Any) â€“ Loaded model used for inference.

  • meta (dict) â€“ Model metadata/config dictionary.

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) â€“ Feature DataFrame containing multiple tickers.

  • tickers (list[str]) â€“ List of ticker symbols to predict.

  • scalers (dict[str, Any], optional) â€“ Optional dict mapping ticker -> fitted scaler.

  • ticker_to_id (dict[str, int], optional) â€“ Optional mapping from ticker to integer ID expected by the model.

  • features (list[str], optional) â€“ Optional explicit feature list to override meta-derived list.

Returns:

DataFrame with columns [â€˜tickerâ€™,â€™pred_vol_â€¦â€™] for available horizons.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

predict_single(model: Any, meta: Dict[str, Any], df: DataFrame, ticker: str, scalers: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, ticker_to_id: Dict[str, int] | None = None, features: List[str] | None = None) → Dict[str, float][source]ïƒ

Predict multi-horizon volatility for a single ticker.

Aligns features to the model schema (adding missing features as zeros, dropping extras), scales inputs with the appropriate per-ticker scaler, runs the model, and formats outputs as {â€˜tickerâ€™, â€˜pred_vol_1â€™, â€˜pred_vol_5â€™, â€¦} using horizons from meta.

Parameters:

  • model (Any) â€“ Loaded model used for inference.

  • meta (dict) â€“ Model metadata/config including â€˜windowâ€™, â€˜horizonsâ€™, and optional â€˜config.target_colâ€™.

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) â€“ Feature DataFrame containing rows for multiple tickers and dates.

  • ticker (str) â€“ Ticker symbol to predict.

  • scalers (dict[str, Any], optional) â€“ Optional dict mapping ticker -> fitted scaler for features.

  • ticker_to_id (dict[str, int], optional) â€“ Optional mapping from ticker to integer ID expected by the model.

  • features (list[str], optional) â€“ Optional explicit feature list to override meta-derived list.

Raises:

ValueError â€“ If there is insufficient data to form the input window.

Returns:

Dictionary with â€˜tickerâ€™ and predicted volatility per horizon.

Return type:

dict[str, float]

volsense_inference.sector_mapping moduleïƒ

VolSense Inference â€” Sector mappings and color palettes.

This module centralizes:

  1. Ticker-to-sector dictionaries for different model universes: - SECTOR_MAP_109: compact universe used by v109 models - SECTOR_MAP_507: extended universe used by v507 models

  2. SECTOR_COLORS: consistent hex colors per sector for plots/dashboards

Helpers:

  • get_sector_map(version): obtain the appropriate tickerâ†’sector map

  • export_to_json(path): write both maps to a JSON file for external use

  • get_color(sector): fetch a stable color for a sector label

Intended for analytics, dashboards, and reporting layers in volsense_inference.

export_to_json(path='sector_map.json')[source]ïƒ

Export available sector maps to a single JSON file.

The JSON contains two top-level keys: â€œv109â€ and â€œv507â€.

Parameters:

path (str) â€“ Filesystem path to write the JSON file.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

volsense_inference.signal_engine moduleïƒ

VolSense Signal Engine (Snapshot Edition)ïƒ

Transforms snapshot forecasts from ForecastEngine or ForecasterAPI into actionable volatility signals and sector-level intelligence.

Key changes vs. prior version:

  • Removed metrics needing time-series history (EMA, momentum, spillover)

  • Treats realized_vol as todayâ€™s realized volatility

  • Renamed realized_vol â†’ today_vol for interpretability

  • Cleaned & vectorized computations for speed

  • Simplified sector-relative rollups and cross-sectional scoring

  • Added cross-sectional sector z-score computation for single-day analysis

class SignalEngine(data: DataFrame | None = None, model_version: str = 'v507')[source]ïƒ

Bases: object

Snapshot signal processor for cross-sectional and sector intelligence.

Converts a one-day, multi-ticker forecast table into z-scores, spreads, ranks, regime flags, and sector-relative statistics.

Parameters:

  • data (pandas.DataFrame, optional) â€“ Optional forecast DataFrame to initialize and standardize.

  • model_version (str) â€“ Sector-map key (â€˜v109â€™ or â€˜v507â€™) used for enrichment.

Variables:

  • df (pandas.DataFrame | None) â€“ Canonical input DataFrame after coercion.

  • signals (pandas.DataFrame | None) â€“ Computed signal DataFrame after compute_signals().

  • sector_map (dict[str, str]) â€“ Mapping of ticker to sector label for the chosen universe.

compute_signals(enrich_with_sectors: bool = True) → DataFrame[source]ïƒ

Compute cross-sectional signals from the snapshot.

Derives per-horizon:

  • vol_zscore: Cross-sectional z-score of forecast_vol

  • vol_spread: (forecast_vol / today_vol) - 1 when today_vol is available

  • xsec_rank: Percentile rank by horizon

  • signal_strength: Rescaled rank in [-1, 1]

  • regime_flag: {â€˜calmâ€™,â€™normalâ€™,â€™spikeâ€™} by z-score thresholds

  • (optional) sector-level rollups and z-scores

Parameters:

enrich_with_sectors (bool) â€“ If True, attach sector labels and sector stats.

Raises:

RuntimeError â€“ If no data has been loaded via set_data().

Returns:

Signal-enriched DataFrame aligned to the canonical schema.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

ticker_summary(ticker: str, horizons: list[int] | None = None, date: Timestamp | None = None, decimals: int = 4) → str[source]ïƒ

Create a human-readable summary for a ticker across horizons.

Includes forecast level, todayâ€™s realized vol, percent spread, z-score, position, regime, sector z-score, and universe rank.

Parameters:

  • ticker (str) â€“ Ticker symbol to summarize.

  • horizons (list[int] | None) â€“ Subset of horizons to include; defaults to all present.

  • date (pandas.Timestamp | None) â€“ Snapshot date; defaults to the max date in signals.

  • decimals (int) â€“ Decimal precision for displayed values.

Returns:

Multi-line summary string for the selected ticker.

Return type:

str

Raises:

RuntimeError â€“ If compute_signals() has not been called.

classify_position(row)[source]ïƒ

Classify a trading position from cross-sectional and term spreads.

Parameters:

row (Mapping[str, float]) â€“ Mapping-like object (e.g. pandas.Series) containing at minimum: vol_zscore (float). Optional keys: vol_spread (float) and term_spread_10v5 (float).

Returns:

Position label: "long", "short", or "neutral".

Return type:

str

Raises:

KeyError â€“ If vol_zscore is missing from row.

Note

Decision thresholds (hard-coded):

  • z-score threshold: > 1.0 â†’ high, < -1.0 â†’ low

  • vol_spread threshold: > 0.07 / < -0.07 (Â±7%)

  • term_spread_10v5 threshold: > 0.035 / < -0.035 (Â±3.5%)

Example

>>> classify_position({'vol_zscore': 1.2, 'vol_spread': 0.08})
'long'
>>> classify_position({'vol_zscore': -1.3, 'term_spread_10v5': -0.05})
'short'
